habitat_description:
Sorex merriami primarily inhabits sagebrush habitats, sometimes with components of rabbitbrush, mountain mahogany, saltbush, antelope bitterbrush, snowberry, and/or grasses  (James, 1953; Hoffman, 1955; Hudson and Bacon, 1956; Starrett and Starrett, 1956; Brown, 1967; Allred, 1973; Gashwiler, 1976; Lindsay and Perry, 1977; Williams, 1984; MacCracken et al., 1985; Mullican, 1986; Ports and McAdoo, 1986; George, 1990; Freeman et al., 1993; Kirkland et al., 1997; Nagorsen et al., 2001; Hafner and Stahlecker, 2002).

It is also commonly found in dry bunchgrass habitats, montane grasslands, shortgrass prairie, dry meadows, and subalpine meadows (James, 1953; Durrant and Lee, 1955; Findley, 1956; Lange, 1959; Brown, 1967; McDaniel, 1967; Pefaur and Hoffman, 1971; Armstrong, 1972; Armstrong et al., 1973; Diersing et al., 1979; George, 1990; Kirkland et al., 1997; Benedict et al., 1999; Nagorsen et al., 2001) and in juniper and pinyon woodlands, savanna, and scrubland (Hoffmeister, 1956; Starrett and Starrett, 1956; Allred, 1973; Armstrong et al., 1973; Williams, 1984).

Additional individuals have been documented in: rabbitbrush shrubland with a bunchgrass understory (Hudson and Bacon, 1956); introduced grasses and forbs (Hooper, 1944; Benedict et al., 1999); forbland on reclamation sites (Kirkland et al., 1997); and herbaceous, post-burn regeneration (Kirkland et al., 1997).

In the Colorado Plateau and southern Rocky Mountain regions, Merriam’s shrew has been documented in: ponderosa pine woodland and savanna (Lange, 1959; Armstrong et al., 1973; Diersing, 1979); parklands, with scattered ponderosa pine, quaking aspen, white fir, and/or Engelmann spruce (Armstrong et al., 1973; George, 1990); as well as steep, north-facing canyon walls forested with Douglas-fir (Hafner and Stahlecker, 2002), though each of these shrews was in close proximity to sagebrush or grassland habitats. No known Merriam's shrews have been found on comparable sites outside of the four corners vicinity (see: Azzerad, 2004; Foresman, 2011)

On two occasions, S. merriami has been captured among hydric willows and rush grass, and the authors noted that “typical habitat” for the shrew was within close proximity to these anomalous capture sites (Hall, 1933; Williams, 1984).

At a coarse resolution, the species’ range coincides with that of sagebrush, but this is more likely related to shared climatic constraints rather than to S. merriami’s reliance on sagebrush itself (Hafner and Stahlecker, 2002).

Elevational constraints for the species are reported to be between 1828 and 3048 m in Colorado (Armstrong et al., 1973), with a comparable maximum elevation of 2896 reported for California (Hoffman, 1955), and observations in Washington state from as low as 197 m in elevation (James, 1953; Hudson and Bacon, 1956)

While occasionally reported close to water (Hall, 1933), an individual has been captured 3.2 km from open water (Lindsay and Perry, 1977), and no known studies have specifically examined hydrologic requirements.
